title: 111_hr299
content: The Act is titled the "National Digital Television Consumer Education Act" and focuses on labeling and consumer education. Section 330 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include new subsection (d) on labeling and consumer education requirements for retail distributors of television receiving equipment without digital tuners. Retail distributors of television receiving equipment without digital tuners must display a consumer alert provided by the manufacturer. The label must be in close vicinity of the unit on display, clearly visible to consumers, and effective 30 days after the enactment of the National Digital Television Consumer Education Act. Additionally, distributors must provide information to consumers through signs and pamphlets. Retail distributors must display consumer alerts on signs and pamphlets for product categories including television receiving equipment without digital tuners. The information should also cover recycling old electronics. Other vendors must comply within 30 days of the National Digital Television Consumer Education Act. The Consumer Education Act requires sellers of television receiving equipment without digital tuners to display a consumer alert at the point of sale. The alert must inform consumers about the lack of a digital tuner and provide information on recycling old electronics. This TV has an analog broadcast tuner and will need a converter box after February 17, 2009, for over-the-air broadcasts. It will still work with cable, satellite TV, gaming consoles, VCRs, DVD players, and similar products. For more information, contact the Federal Communications Commission or visit www.dtv.gov. After February 17, 2009, this TV will require a converter box for over-the-air broadcasts due to the national transition to digital TV. It will still work with cable, satellite TV, gaming consoles, VCRs, DVD players, and similar products. For more information, contact the Federal Communications Commission at 1-888-225-5322 or visit www.dtv.gov. The consumer advisory label must be displayed on devices and their retail packaging. Television broadcasters must air 120 seconds of public service announcements daily, and video distributors must include a notice with each bill until March 31, 2009. The announcements and notices required by this paragraph educate consumers about the deadline for termination of analog television broadcasting, equipment options after termination, converter box voucher program, and steps to redeem the voucher. SEC. 159. DIGITAL TELEVISION CONSUMER EDUCATION GRANT PROGRAM. This section establishes a grant program to educate consumers about the transition to digital television broadcasting. The Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information is authorized to establish a temporary grant program for a nationwide consumer education campaign on digital television conversion. A single grant will be awarded to a qualified entity by January 31, 2009, representing noncommercial TV stations nationally. The Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information is authorized to establish a temporary grant program for a nationwide consumer education campaign on digital television conversion. Various groups including manufacturers, retailers, and consumer advocacy groups are involved. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009, with expenditures terminating on April 30, 2009. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL FUNDS FOR THE CONVERTER BOX COUPON PROGRAM. Amendment to increase funds for the converter box coupon program from $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion. Conforming amendment to adjust funds in the Communications Act of 1934 from $7.363 billion to $7.163 billion.
